Matpakke means “packed lunch”. If you pack a burrito, then that's your matpakke. You could pack a bowl of salad, and it would still be a matpakke.

A person from Norway might usually pack a very simple sandwich with liver pate and multiple pieces of bread, but she could also bring lompe or lefse (flat bread) and it would still be a matpakke.

Matpakke is food you bring from home to work, school or a trip, it's not a type of sandwich

The Norwegian matpakke is just a sandwich wrapped in paper that you usually bring either to school/work or maybe on a mountain hike. The word consists of two words. Mat(food) + pakke (package). The filling can be whatever you like.

Tacos are sandwiches.

If bread is on both sides of a thing, it's a sandwich.
If bread is flat underneath a thing, it's a pizza.
If bread is folded to hold a thing, it's a taco.
If bread is wrapped to contain a thing, it's a burrito.

If it's a hot pocket, it isn't food, stop trying to call it food. ;)

1:05 Don't forget contronym: one word with two or more contradictory/opposite meanings. I.e the verb "dust". As in "I dust the house", which means to remove particles from the house and "I dust for fingerprints" to add particles to see fingerprints.

Taboos and euphemisms can go so far that they erase a word from usage. 'Bear', in almost every European language, means 'brown thing'; they have determined that this is a euphemism to avoid saying the animal's real name and avoid its wrath. It worked so well that that real name is no longer known.

The Polish example is cloooooose but not 100%. wiedzieć is used for intransitive sentences with one exception, being wiem to, i know that (the fact thing)
znać is used for transitive sentences. not just people, but answers, words, etc.

The sandwich problem actually has a sufficient solution: A sandwich is a horizontal-layered, non-enclosed food made to be eaten with the hands, i.e. "handheld", the top and bottom of which - not counting garnish or toppings - are the same ingredient, that contain a nonzero number of layered ingredients between them, all of which are meant to be eaten simultaneously (i.e. in bites through all layers). Here is a list of some food items to consider, and their categorization, based on this definition:

Ice cream sandwich: Sandwich
Ravioli: Not a sandwich (Enclosed, and not eaten with the hands)
Hamburger: Sandwich
Poptart: Not a sandwich (Enclosed)
KFC Double Down: Sandwich
Burrito: Not a sandwich (Enclosed, i.e. wrapped - not sandwiched - and not defined by horizontal layers)
Sub: Sandwich (Despite the top and bottom halves of the bread remaining connected, it is not fully wrapped (i.e. stuffed), and satisfies all criteria, as the layers are still horizontal)
Meatball sub: Not a sandwich (not held or eaten horizontally, typically; the filling is cradled; not sandwiched)
Corndog: Not a sandwich (obviously fails a number of criteria)
Lettuce wrap: Not a sandwich (wrapped; not sandwiched; and not defined by horizontal layering)
Crepes: Depending on the serving method, it can be a type of sandwich (they form a Venn diagram with sandwiches)
Pizza: Not a sandwich (top and bottom are not the same; satisfies all other criteria, but remains not a sandwich)
Calzone: Not a sandwich (enclosed)
Gyro: Not a sandwich (surrounding bread is wrapped/cradling the filling, and this not horizontally layered)
Pancake stack: Not a sandwich (Not handheld, i.e. eaten with fork and knife, and not defaultedly eaten simultaneously)
Pie: Not a sandwich (Not handheld... typically)
Hostess Fruit Pies: Not a sandwich (enclosed)
Oreos: Technically a type of very small, bite-sized, confectionery sandwich. A very atypical sandwich, but an Oreo is a sandwich. A very small, sweet one.
Cake: Not a sandwich (Decidedly not a handheld food, as well as all layers not defaultedly consumed simultaneously)
Lasagna: Although layered, not only are the top and bottom layers not necessarily the same, it is not handheld.
Tiramisu: See lasagna
A quesadilla: A sandwich, and a surprising example of one. But it acts like an incredibly thin sandwich in all ways.
Chicken and waffles: A sandwich, if you put the chicken (ideally without bones) between two waffle quarters, pick it up, and eat it like that; in that situation, you made a sandwich.
A S'more: A sandwich
A taco: Not a sandwich (the interior layers may be horizontal, but the outer layers - the shell - are vertical, and not aligned the same as the interior layers; also see Meatball sub)
Whipped cream between two apple slices: An unusual sandwich, but it is a sandwich.
A fish between two blocks of cheese: A really weird sandwich, but it would be a sandwich, if you ate it like that.

Of additional note is that sandwiches may be very big, but can be cut into smaller sections, even to make individual bite-sized, smaller sandwiches, such as might be found on a platter, at a party. One might expect items such as pie, lasagna, cake, and tiramisu to be excluded for the sectioning of how they are served. This is not so. Many sandwiches get cut, for example, diagonally, into smaller parts of a sandwich, which may be considered their own sandwiches. Additionally, it may be a potential criterion that the exterior layers be rigid enough to hold their structure when held in the hands (gravy between two layers of mashed potatoes might not count as a sandwich).

In Philippine English or the English dialect used in the Philippines by Filipinos, a toilet, toilet room, bathroom, or a wash room, is called a "comfort room" or abbreviated as a "C.R." or "CR". It's maybe because we Filipinos find this particular place as a place where you can be comfortable or where you can feel comfort, but I just don't know the exact reason why and its specific origin and history.

There's a really nice TED talk (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F6NU0DMjv0Y) that goes into how dictionaries work and what makes a word "real". At the end of the day, what words and phrases mean comes down to how people use them in context, which is why you can get a phrase like "I could care less" to mean "I don't care", even though that is literally the one thing it rules out. Whatever works!

If I don't know a word, I look it up but I also find sentences using that word and form my own sentences using that word. Practice and using the new words in your writing and speech helps move that word from your short term to your long term memory.
